entry.title: Starting Fresh with Jekyll
entry.content:
Starting Fresh with Jekyll

February 20, 2015 Case-Study 0 Comments

I am a Designer, Illustrator, and Front-End Developer from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania living in Chicago, Illinois.

Background

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

Objectives

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

2. User-Experience

Planning/Research

Sal and Mustafa staked out their competition well before bringing me onboard and discovered the space for innovation is huge: Not a single business for finding after-school activities showed up in Google Search — Only definitions for after-school activity, reasons why aftershool activities are fun, and a few government-run organizations.

It was concluded that the closest competition in after-school class discovery was a San Francisco-based startup, called Kidfully; it focused on the social aspect of reviewing and sharing after-school activities with fellow parents, a direction similar, but not the same as Afterskoolz.

Afterskoolz would be less about recommendations and building a social community (i.e Kidfully, Yelp, Angie's List), and more about shopping and registering— making it more similar to traditional shopping sites, such as Amazon or even Grubhub.

User Studies

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Wireframes

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Site-Map

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Prototyping

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

3. User-Interface

Homepage

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Search Results

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Class Details

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Dashboards

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

4. Details

Logo

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Style Guide

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Style Guide

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

5. Wrap Up

Conclusion

The timeframe for this project was aproximately late July, 2014 to Mid November, 2014. We had originally planned for only a non-responsive desktop experience built only search-and-register functionality. Over the course of the four months, the scope gradually increased— adding responsiveness, as well as a wide array of backend tool for users. By the end of the process, Afterskoolz became a multifunctional platform for not only parents, but teachers and principals.

All-in-all, I'm very happy with the direction I created for Sal and Mustafa; I believe we nailed down the fundamentals of their product and have left room for it to grow. As in all the projects, there are specifics I

Future

Over the course of a project, you inherently become better and smarter; you know find your mistakes in the first month and so on. However, it is impossible to move forward if you keep looking back. One of the hardest things you can do is say: "Hey, this isn't perfect. There's a lot of things I'd like to change now that I know better, but we'll cross that bridge later." The main thing is delivering a solid product so it can be developed and launched. That's why it's called an MVP.

But, that's not to say I didn't put together ideas for Afterskoolz V.2. One of things I wanted to improve was the homepage, overall color variety, navigation, and search funtionality.

Outside of my suggested revisions, additional platform features are in the pipeline as well, such as social networking functionality, widgets, and iOS/Android apps.

entry.title: One Fingerprint to Rule Them All
entry.content:
One Fingerprint to Rule Them All

17 Feb 2015 Case-Study 0 Comments

1. Introduction

At a glance

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

Background

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

Objectives

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

2. User-Experience

Planning/Research

Sal and Mustafa staked out their competition well before bringing me onboard and discovered the space for innovation is huge: Not a single business for finding after-school activities showed up in Google Search — Only definitions for after-school activity, reasons why aftershool activities are fun, and a few government-run organizations.

It was concluded that the closest competition in after-school class discovery was a San Francisco-based startup, called Kidfully; it focused on the social aspect of reviewing and sharing after-school activities with fellow parents, a direction similar, but not the same as Afterskoolz.

Afterskoolz would be less about recommendations and building a social community (i.e Kidfully, Yelp, Angie's List), and more about shopping and registering— making it more similar to traditional shopping sites, such as Amazon or even Grubhub.

User Studies

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Wireframes

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Site-Map

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Prototyping

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

3. User-Interface

Homepage

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Search Results

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Class Details

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Dashboards

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

4. Details

Logo

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Style Guide

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Style Guide

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

5. Wrap Up

Conclusion

The timeframe for this project was aproximately late July, 2014 to Mid November, 2014. We had originally planned for only a non-responsive desktop experience built only search-and-register functionality. Over the course of the four months, the scope gradually increased— adding responsiveness, as well as a wide array of backend tool for users. By the end of the process, Afterskoolz became a multifunctional platform for not only parents, but teachers and principals.

All-in-all, I'm very happy with the direction I created for Sal and Mustafa; I believe we nailed down the fundamentals of their product and have left room for it to grow. As in all the projects, there are specifics I

Future

Over the course of a project, you inherently become better and smarter; you know find your mistakes in the first month and so on. However, it is impossible to move forward if you keep looking back. One of the hardest things you can do is say: "Hey, this isn't perfect. There's a lot of things I'd like to change now that I know better, but we'll cross that bridge later." The main thing is delivering a solid product so it can be developed and launched. That's why it's called an MVP.

But, that's not to say I didn't put together ideas for Afterskoolz V.2. One of things I wanted to improve was the homepage, overall color variety, navigation, and search funtionality.

Outside of my suggested revisions, additional platform features are in the pipeline as well, such as social networking functionality, widgets, and iOS/Android apps.

If you have any questions or comments, please post them below. If you liked this post, you can share it with your followers or follow me on Twitter.

entry.title: The Best Way to find After-School Classes for Your Kids
entry.content:
The Best Way to find After-School Classes for Your Kids

December 12, 2014  | Case-Study  | 0 Comments

Background

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

Objectives

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

  • Craft Afterskoolz Brand

    I would design logo, branding guidelines, illustrations, and iconography that will be used in all facets of Afterskoolz product

2. User-Experience

Planning/Research

Sal and Mustafa staked out their competition well before bringing me onboard and discovered the space for innovation is huge: Not a single business for finding after-school activities showed up in Google Search — Only definitions for after-school activity, reasons why aftershool activities are fun, and a few government-run organizations.

It was concluded that the closest competition in after-school class discovery was a San Francisco-based startup, called Kidfully; it focused on the social aspect of reviewing and sharing after-school activities with fellow parents, a direction similar, but not the same as Afterskoolz.

Afterskoolz would be less about recommendations and building a social community (i.e Kidfully, Yelp, Angie's List), and more about shopping and registering— making it more similar to traditional shopping sites, such as Amazon or even Grubhub.

User Studies

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Wireframes

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Site-Map

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Prototyping

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

3. User-Interface

Homepage

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Search Results

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Class Details

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Dashboards

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

4. Details

Logo

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Style Guide

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Style Guide

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

5. Wrap Up

Conclusion

The timeframe for this project was aproximately late July, 2014 to Mid November, 2014. We had originally planned for only a non-responsive desktop experience built only search-and-register functionality. Over the course of the four months, the scope gradually increased— adding responsiveness, as well as a wide array of backend tool for users. By the end of the process, Afterskoolz became a multifunctional platform for not only parents, but teachers and principals.

All-in-all, I'm very happy with the direction I created for Sal and Mustafa; I believe we nailed down the fundamentals of their product and have left room for it to grow. As in all the projects, there are specifics I

Future

Over the course of a project, you inherently become better and smarter; you know find your mistakes in the first month and so on. However, it is impossible to move forward if you keep looking back. One of the hardest things you can do is say: "Hey, this isn't perfect. There's a lot of things I'd like to change now that I know better, but we'll cross that bridge later." The main thing is delivering a solid product so it can be developed and launched. That's why it's called an MVP.

But, that's not to say I didn't put together ideas for Afterskoolz V.2. One of things I wanted to improve was the homepage, overall color variety, navigation, and search funtionality.

Outside of my suggested revisions, additional platform features are in the pipeline as well, such as social networking functionality, widgets, and iOS/Android apps.

If you have any questions or comments, please post them below. If you liked this post, you can share it with your followers or follow me on Twitter.

entry.title: The World Revolves Around the Sun
entry.content:
The World Revolves Around the Sun

15 Feb 2015 Case-Study 0 Comments

1. Introduction

At a glance

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

Background

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

Objectives

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

2. User-Experience

Planning/Research

Sal and Mustafa staked out their competition well before bringing me onboard and discovered the space for innovation is huge: Not a single business for finding after-school activities showed up in Google Search — Only definitions for after-school activity, reasons why aftershool activities are fun, and a few government-run organizations.

It was concluded that the closest competition in after-school class discovery was a San Francisco-based startup, called Kidfully; it focused on the social aspect of reviewing and sharing after-school activities with fellow parents, a direction similar, but not the same as Afterskoolz.

Afterskoolz would be less about recommendations and building a social community (i.e Kidfully, Yelp, Angie's List), and more about shopping and registering— making it more similar to traditional shopping sites, such as Amazon or even Grubhub.

User Studies

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Wireframes

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Site-Map

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Prototyping

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

3. User-Interface

Homepage

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Search Results

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Class Details

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

Dashboards

The homepage, like in most projects, tends to draw the most input from clients; they usually have a pretty clear vision for how they want to present their product and the atmosphere they want to create for prospective visitors.

Because of this, the back-and-forth between myself and the client tends to take far longer than any other aspect of the website's UI. In designing the Afterskoolz homepage, the main areas of concern from the client was picking a powerful (yet friendly) hero image, a very direct search CTA, and a fun way to list the available classes.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.

4. Details

Logo

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Style Guide

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

Style Guide

Afterskoolz was built with four types of users: Parents, Teachers, Principals, and Adminsitrators — all with very unique set of needs:

The needs of the users determined what functionality the product needed. Many new features were added, while some earlier proposed ideas were reinforced, and other axed.

5. Wrap Up

Conclusion

The timeframe for this project was aproximately late July, 2014 to Mid November, 2014. We had originally planned for only a non-responsive desktop experience built only search-and-register functionality. Over the course of the four months, the scope gradually increased— adding responsiveness, as well as a wide array of backend tool for users. By the end of the process, Afterskoolz became a multifunctional platform for not only parents, but teachers and principals.

All-in-all, I'm very happy with the direction I created for Sal and Mustafa; I believe we nailed down the fundamentals of their product and have left room for it to grow. As in all the projects, there are specifics I

Future

Over the course of a project, you inherently become better and smarter; you know find your mistakes in the first month and so on. However, it is impossible to move forward if you keep looking back. One of the hardest things you can do is say: "Hey, this isn't perfect. There's a lot of things I'd like to change now that I know better, but we'll cross that bridge later." The main thing is delivering a solid product so it can be developed and launched. That's why it's called an MVP.

But, that's not to say I didn't put together ideas for Afterskoolz V.2. One of things I wanted to improve was the homepage, overall color variety, navigation, and search funtionality.

Outside of my suggested revisions, additional platform features are in the pipeline as well, such as social networking functionality, widgets, and iOS/Android apps.

If you have any questions or comments, please post them below. If you liked this post, you can share it with your followers or follow me on Twitter.

Related

  • Starting Fresh with Jekyll
    20 Feb 2015 0 Comments
  • One Fingerprint to Rule Them All
    17 Feb 2015 Case-Study 0 Comments
  • The Best Way to find After-School Classes for Your Kids
    16 Feb 2015 Case-Study 0 Comments
  • The World Revolves Around the Sun
    15 Feb 2015 Case-Study 0 Comments
  • Bringing the News to the Carribean
    14 Feb 2015 Case-Study 0 Comments
  • Redesigning the Pioneer Press
    13 Feb 2015 Case-Study 0 Comments

entry.title: Redesigning the Pioneer Press
entry.content:
Redesigning the Pioneer Press

December 12, 2014  | Case-Study  | 0 Comments

1. Introduction

At a glance

In the summer of 2014, I was approached by my former Aggrego co-worker, Sal Abassi, to help get a personal project off the ground; that project would be Afterskoolz. As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

Background

As a parent, he felt there was an opportunity to create a platform to make finding and planning after-school activiites for his children easier.

Sal, alongside fellow parent and Afterskoolz co-founder, Mustafa Patni, laid out a rough draft of all the features they wanted Afterskoolz to have, such as simple search functionality, class registration, teacher-to-parent messaging, and a schedule-overlayed calendar. With their vision laid out, it was my job to bring it to life.

Outside of solving for the client's main concerns, I wanted to make sure the homepage got the Afterskoolz branding across in a tasteful, subtle manner. It's pretty standard in modern design practices for homepages to be: Hero image, CTA, and product selling points.

I followed this formula pretty closely and added illustrations to compliment the various sections. By going relatively simple, the homepage responded down to tablet and mobile very nicely.
